ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained significant knowledge into classical computer vision (image formation, image processing, edge detection, image representations, CNNs, image classification, object detection); significantly improved skills in function, clear, and modular coding and skills in coding computer vision algorithms (e.g., object detection); and insights I didn't have before about how modern and classical computer vision operate on the same basic paradigms.
A solid introduction to computer vision and neural networks.

I learned a ton about computer vision including the basics like filters and convolutions. Also about edge, corner, and blob detection. Plus, neural networks for image classification and object detection.
The fundamental mechanisms behind convolution/CNNs, non-maximal suppression, and a host of other topics in vision.
Computer vision techniques
Basic Computer Vision concepts to advanced concepts in Neural Networks.

I learned the notions and tools of projective geometry, learnt how 3D objects can be projected into a 2D image and then reconstructed, and various ways of manipulating images, including creation of gaussian pyramids. The course culminates in the study of CNN. Overall, this is a great introduction to both classical and neural computer vision.

I learned a lot of classical (non-learning-based) methods for computer vision, including image formation, blurring, edge and corner detection, feature detection, and image alignment. I also learned about some learning-based methods for computer vision, including deep neural nets (DNNs), convolutional neural nets (CNNs), object detection techniques, and image segmentation techniques. 
In addition to learning about specific techniques, we also talked about the general framework for most computer vision tasks, which can be used to understand almost any new technique.
I get to know the field of computer vision and gained solid understanding of the field's basics.
Homogeneous coordinates, image classification, image segmentation.
Fundamental algorithms on computer vision tasks
Basic concepts and hands-on skills in CV.
Understanding of kernels/filters, ML methods like PCA, CNNs, NNs, understanding of image composition. Equal parts code and theory.
basic knowledge about cv and cnn
pretty hard but rewarding

I learned the concepts behind classical image processing techniques and how to implement them in python. This course mostly focused on classical techniques like edge, corner, and feature detection, but also covered machine learning topics like image classification and object detection.

I learned about the important problems in the field of computer vision and how progress has been made to solve them over the years. I learned about the various algorithmic components that have been developed and how they have pushed the boundaries of what's possible further.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of this course is absolutely Professor Alex Wong's teaching! He is hands-down the best teacher I've had (for a non-seminar course). He is clearly passionate about the subject material, knowledgeable about the theoretical basics and the cutting-edge applications, and engages the class through questions and in-class coding (and he will learn your name, which certainly cannot be said about most lecture courses!). Another strength of the course is the material covered; it achieved a good depth and breadth. The only weakness of this class is that the exercises and assignments did not cover all course material, so I leave the course feeling weaker on the material I did not have the chance to practice. I believe the exercises were about every 1.5-2 weeks, but I would suggest having a short weekly exercise so material is constantly being reviewed and practiced.

The exercises and assignments did a good job covering important aspects of the lecture, and the lecture slides were also well-organized. However, feedback was very delayed, especially for the first half of the semester.
The course was structured very welleach concept built off of the previous concepts. I found that each assignment was very helpful in helping me make sure I knew each concept.
The lectures work in a logical sequence, the coursework is fair and clearly outlined.
Class was disorganized in some sense and the grading was very delayed without much feedback on the assignments
Maybe some check-ins to ensure people understand the material well enough.

The strengths are succinct and condensed lecture notes which are comprehensive and fairly concise (w/o unnecessary verbosity). There is great cohesion and clarity in the whole course.

A weakness is probably the fact that this course doesn't require strong python experience, so some lectures are spent on working on quite simple exercises. But I guess to people who don't have a lot of experience with Python this is not a weakness.

Another weakness is that the assignments were graded a bit slowly.

Strengths: I liked Professor Wong's lectures, and I thought he did a good job explaining the concepts. I liked that we started the exercises in class, and I thought the exercises and assignments were helpful in reinforcing my understanding of the content they covered.
Weaknesses: I wish we'd spent a bit more time on learning-based methods, because they seem to be the present and future of computer vision. Also, I think I would have learned the material more thoroughly if there had been more homework (maybe more coding, or maybe some pencil-and-paper exercises) and exams. As the course is structured, there were many topics with which I didn't have to engage very deeply. The exercises and assignments couldn't cover everything, and because we got so much guidance on them, you could almost complete them fully understanding all the content. At the end of the semester, it was a little difficult to motivate myself to pay attention to lectures about complex learning-based topics, because even though I found it really interesting and wanted to know more about it, I also knew I would never be assessed on my knowledge of it (since there was no final exam, and it wasn't part of my final project). I think this content could lend itself reasonably well to an exam, and that would have forced me to really engage with and understand everything.
The course is very well designed -- the concepts are very interesting and the lectures are excellent.

Strengths: Alex is a very engaging lecture! He is super nice and considerate! 
Weaknesses: The assignments designed are not very tightly associated with the concepts we learn in lecture, or rather, I do not feel like my knowledge about the topics was enhanced significantly after completing the assignments. In addition, personally, it was only when I started to do the final project that I felt I had truly grasped the baseline of computer vision. I think that the lecture materials are a bit disorganized.
Relatively simple and straightforward concepts, covers most of the basic topics needed for CV. Might benefit from less interactive time between professor and students to speed up the pace.
The course was good.
Well structured curriculum.
The professor is enthusiastic about teaching and the classes are very engaging. It would be helpful if there are forums to post questions.

The course was very effective at teaching the concepts behind image processing techniques. The workload was very manageable, and the in class exercises and homeworks really helped solidify the concepts, though could be pretty confusing.

Strength:

Weekly exercises, biweekly assignments and a final project. These are great for gaining practical knowledge which is vital in an empirical field such as this.

Weakness:

I think the course will benefit from having graded examinations so that students are forced to study the material. This would definitely improve how they are able to recall the material two, five or ten years from now. 

Ideally, students should be doing this automatically, but from my personal experience, I'm not going to prioritize revising the course when I have 10 other things to do unless there is an official reason to do it. While this is unfortunate, it is not very unreasonable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Computer Vision is one of the main pillars of machine learning and has many applications. It's great to actually understand computer vision at the basic level.
Yes, the content is very interesting, and Professor Wong is a great lecturer.
Yes, anyone interested in computer vision topics will really enjoy this course.
Yes - fairly low workload if that's important to you, but there is plenty to learn from the lectures - Alex puts plenty of care into them which is plain to see.

Definitely recommend this class if you're interested in a primer on computer vision and the fundamental principles that are used in the field. The PSETs do a good job of surveying most of these areas, though the final project definitely feels rushed towards the end of the semester and without any guardrails so I'd recommend you find a good partner to do the project with.
Yes, it's a good intro course to build a strong foundation of the basics of CV
Not if they are not willing to put in a lot of outside time to self study the material
Yes! Computer vision is one of the hottest research directions and this is a great introduction to the field

I liked this class. We spent the majority of the class on classical, non-learning-based methods, and I thought it was cool to learn how much can be done without resorting to neural networks and very complex tools. The workload was very manageable, although at times I felt that the lack of work meant that I wasn't learning as deeply as I could have.
The topics of the course are super interesting and the lectures are amazing.

Yes, if they are interested in computer vision. Alex does a great job leading you in the realm of computer vision! Plus, if you want a relatively chill course, I think the workload of this course is just right! Alex is a very helpful and engaging lecturer, so you won't feel bored during lectures.
Great for getting into CV
Yes. I learned lots of things from the course. The course was excellent.
Yes!
Yes, it's an interesting CS course
if you're interested in vision specifically and have the math background
I would recommend this course for students looking to learn about fundamental vision concepts and how to implement them in python
Yes.
